user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_SocketOpen_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_SocketOpen_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int                             os_domain;
    int                             os_type;
    int                             os_proto;
    int                             os_flags;
    OS_impl_file_internal_record_t *impl;
    OS_stream_internal_record_t *   stream;

    impl   = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_filehandle_table, *token);
    stream = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_stream_table, *token);

    os_proto = 0;

    switch (stream->socket_type)
    {
        case OS_SocketType_DATAGRAM:
            os_type  = SOCK_DGRAM;
            os_proto = IPPROTO_UDP;
            break;

        case OS_SocketType_STREAM:
            os_type  = SOCK_STREAM;
            os_proto = IPPROTO_TCP;
            break;

        default:
            return OS_ERR_NOT_IMPLEMENTED;
    }

    switch (stream->socket_domain)
    {
        case OS_SocketDomain_INET:
            os_domain = AF_INET;
            break;
#ifdef OS_NETWORK_SUPPORTS_IPV6
        case OS_SocketDomain_INET6:
            os_domain = AF_INET6;
            break;
#endif
        default:
            return OS_ERR_NOT_IMPLEMENTED;
    }

    impl->fd = socket(os_domain, os_type, os_proto);
    if (impl->fd < 0)
    {
        return OS_ERROR;
    }

    /*
     * Setting the REUSEADDR flag helps during debugging when there might be frequent
     * code restarts.  However if setting the option fails then it is not worth bailing out over.
     */
    os_flags = 1;
    setsockopt(impl->fd, SOL_SOCKET, SO_REUSEADDR, &os_flags, sizeof(os_flags));

    /*
     * Set the standard options on the filehandle by default --
     * this may set it to non-blocking mode if the implementation supports it.
     * any blocking would be done explicitly via the select() wrappers
     *
     * NOTE: The implementation still generally works without this flag set, but
     * nonblock mode does improve robustness in the event that multiple tasks
     * attempt to accept new connections from the same server socket at the same time.
     */
    OS_IMPL_SET_SOCKET_FLAGS(token);

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_SocketOpen_Impl:
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
#define OS_IMPL_SET_SOCKET_FLAGS(tok) OS_SetSocketDefaultFlags_Impl(tok)
...
extern OS_impl_file_internal_record_t OS_impl_filehandle_table[OS_MAX_NUM_OPEN_FILES]
...
extern OS_stream_internal_record_t OS_stream_table[OS_MAX_NUM_OPEN_FILES]
...
typedef struct
{
    int  fd;
    bool selectable;
} OS_impl_file_internal_record_t
...
typedef struct
{
    char   stream_name[OS_MAX_PATH_LEN];
    uint8  socket_domain;
    uint8  socket_type;
    uint16 stream_state;
} OS_stream_internal_record_t
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
#define OS_NETWORK_SUPPORTS_IPV6 
...
#define OS_ERR_NOT_IMPLEMENTED (-28)
...
#define OS_ERROR (-1)
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I found no uses of compiler-specific language extensions in the provided code. In particular:
- No GCC/Clang/MSC-specific keywords or constructs are present (for example: __attribute__, __asm, __builtin_*, __typeof__, typeof, statement-expressions ({ ... }), nested functions, or MSVC __declspec). 
- All macros used are standard C preprocessor macros and conditional compilation (#ifdef) — not language extensions. The OS_* identifiers (e.g. OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET, OS_IMPL_SET_SOCKET_FLAGS) are normal macro expansions, and their expansions shown are standard function/macro calls. 
- Types like int32, uint8, uint16, and bool appear to be typedefs or standard bool from <stdbool.h>, not compiler-specific extensions. 
- Standard library/socket functions (socket, setsockopt) and numeric macros are platform APIs, not compiler language extensions.

Therefore there are no fragments that require further investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 (language extensions should not be used). If you expect to treat any project-specific macros or typedefs as extensions, provide their compiler documentation or definitions indicating they rely on compiler-specific features.
